protocol_name: High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio, Nanopore MinION
protocol_name_html: High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio, Nanopore MinION
public_fork_note: Minor update to contents of lysis buffer. Emphasis on multiple Ampure bead clean ups before starting MinIon library prep. These multiple bead clean-ups have significantly improved our size distributions on the MinIon runs.
description:
Extraction of high quality DNA for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio and MinIon

Optimized for DNA extraction from Bipolaris sorokiniana. Also tested on Parastaognospora nodorum, Zymoseptoria tritici, wheat stripe rust, barley stripe rust and Pyrenophora tritici-repentis

Buffers are best when fresh and not older than 3-6 months. Buffered Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamylalcohol (25:24:1) should not be older than 3 months.

Critical steps to obtain high quality DNA:

  • Do NOT heat samples during DNA extractions! Perform all steps at RT or 4oC as indicated.
  • Do NOT incubate samples with KAc for prolonged time periods
  • Perform two steps of buffered Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamylalcohol purification to reduce co-purifying metabolites.

 

DNA fragments were well above the 40kb mark based on Pippin Pulse Gels. The sequencing center performed a second AMPure purification step before library construction.

fork_info.protocol_name: High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio
fork_info.protocol_name_html: High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio

groups.group_name: MinION user group for high molecular weight DNA extraction from all kingdoms

guidelines:
Modified from protocols of Prof. Pietro Spanu (Imperial College, London) and T. M.

Fulton, J. Chunwongse, S. D. Tanksley, Pl Mol Biol Rep 13, 207 (1995)

I am gratefull for critical suggestion from the following scientists.
Dr. Claire Anderson, Dr. Andril Gryganskyi, and Dr. David Hayward.

Optimized for DNA extraction from wheat stripe rust spores and also tested on barley leaf rust

Buffers are best when fresh and not older than 3-6 months. Buffered Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamylalcohol (25:24:1) should not be older than 3 months.

 

Critical steps to obtain high quality DNA:

  • Do NOT heat samples during DNA extractions! Perform all steps at RT or 4oC as indicated.
  • Do NOT incubate samples with KAc for prolonged time periods
  • Perform two steps of buffered Phenol:Chloroform:Isoamylalcohol purification to reduce co-purifying metabolites.

 

Reagents required

BUFFER A: 0.35 M sorbitol

0.1 M Tris-HCl

5 mM EDTA, pH 8

autoclave to sterilize

 

BUFFER B: 0.2 M Tris-HCl

50 mM EDTA, pH 8

2 M NaCl

2% CTAB

autoclave to sterilize

 

BUFFER C: 5% Sarkosyl N-lauroylsarcosine sodium salt (SIGMA L5125)

Filter-sterilize

 

Other solutions:

Potassium Acetate 5M (KAc precipitate polysaccharides) pH 7.5

Polyvinylpyrrolidone (40000 MW) 10 % [w/v] (Sigma PVP40)

Polyvinylpyrrolidone (10000 MW) 10% [w/v] (Sigma PVP10)

Sodium Acetate (NaAc) 3M pH 5.2

Filter-sterilize

 

Isopropanol 100%

Ethanol 70%

Buffered Phenol:Chloroforme:Isoamylalcool P:C:I (25:24:1, Sigma P2069)

Autoclave acid washed Sand

 

Enzymes

RNAse A or T1 (1000 U/ml, Thermo Fisher EN0541)

Proteinase K (800U/ml, NEB P81072)

 
AMPure beads from Beckman


Lysis Buffer For 14 ml for 500 mg starting material

2.5 volume of Buffer A 5 mL

2.5 volume of Buffer B 5 mL

1.0 volume of Buffer C 2 mL

PVP 40 10%                 1mL

PVP 10 10%                 1mL
status_info: We use this protocol in our group and it is working

components.data:
Make lysis buffer by mixing buffer A+B+C+PVP10+PVP40 in 50mL Falcon tubes.
All following steps are based on 14 mL lysis buffer as starting volume.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Make lysis buffer by mixing buffer A+B+C+PVP10+PVP40 in 50mL Falcon tubes.
All following steps are based on 14 mL lysis buffer as starting volume.
Add 10uL (10kU) RNAse A to lysis buffer

components.data: Grind tissue/spores with liquid nitrogen in a mortar with sand, use 1g of sand per 100mg of starting material. Grind for 2 mins in 4x 15 sec bursts adding liquid nitrogen after each 15 sec grinding burst.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Grind tissue/spores with liquid nitrogen in a mortar with sand, use 1g of sand per 100mg of starting material. Grind for 2 mins in 4x 15 sec bursts adding liquid nitrogen after each 15 sec grinding burst.

components.data: Transfer powder to 50mL Falcon containing lysis buffer and RNAse, mix well by vortexing
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer powder to 50mL Falcon containing lysis buffer and RNAse, mix well by vortexing

components.data: Incubate at RT for 30 mins mixing by inversion every 5 mins
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate at RT for 30 mins mixing by inversion every 5 mins

components.data: Add 200uL Proteinase K, incubate at RT for 30 mins mixing by inversion every 5 mins
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 200uL Proteinase K, incubate at RT for 30 mins mixing by inversion every 5 mins
Cool on ice for 5 mins

components.data: Add 2.8 mL (0.2 vol) of KAc 5M, mix by inversion, incubate on ice for max 5 mins
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 2.8 mL (0.2 vol) of KAc 5M, mix by inversion, incubate on ice for max 5 mins
Spin at 4<sup>o</sup>C and 5000g for 12 mins

components.data:
Transfer supernatant to fresh Falcon tube containing 17 mL (~1vol) (P/C/I) and mix by inversion for 2 mins.

 

Supernatant may/may not have a lipid layer on the top (depends on the fungus), I don't really see a difference if I take this layer or not into the phenol/choroform mix. I try to not take too much of it to make the next steps slightly easier.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:

source_data.annotation:
A quick question about this step. I get a thick sticky layer at the top (I assume the lipid layer?), then liquid below which I take but I am not seeing a pellet. I am not sure if I am taking the correct layer. Is this what you see?   

Many thanks

source_data.description: Spin at 4 °C and 4000g for 10 mins

components.data: Transfer supernatant (might be milky but do not worry) to fresh Falcon tube containing 17 ml (~1vol) P/C/I and mix by inversion for 2 mins
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer supernatant (might be milky but do not worry) to fresh Falcon tube containing 17 ml (~1vol) P/C/I and mix by inversion for 2 mins
Spin at 4 °C and 4000g for 10 mins
Add 1.5mL (~0.1vol) NaAc and mix by inversion

components.data: Add 15mL (~1vol) RT isopropanol and mix by inversion
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 15mL (~1vol) RT isopropanol and mix by inversion
Incubate at RT for 5-10mins
Spin at 4 °C and 8000g for 30 mins

components.data:
Carefully pour off supernatant.

DNA will form a mostly translucent to white film/pellet at the bottom of the tube (colour may vary depending on your fungus).
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Carefully pour off supernatant.

DNA will form a mostly translucent to white film/pellet at the bottom of the tube (colour may vary depending on your fungus).

components.data:
Pour off EtOH wash untill about 0.5 mL remaining. Gently dislodge pellet with 1mL pipette tip  and pour pellet with remaining 70% EtOH into fresh 1.5mL eppendorf tube.

 

If DNA is not quite pure (as is the case for some fungal DNA extractions), pellet will be brittle and will break into small pieces. Try to recover as much as possible with 1mL pipette.

If the pellet breaks apart too much, add 1.5mL fresh 70% EtOH to the 50mL Faclon and spin for 5min at 4000g.

Remove 1mL and transfer the remaining volume and DNA pellet to same 2mL eppendorf tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Pour off EtOH wash untill about 0.5 mL remaining. Gently dislodge pellet with 1mL pipette tip  and pour pellet with remaining 70% EtOH into fresh 1.5mL eppendorf tube.

 

If DNA is not quite pure (as is the case for some fungal DNA extractions), pellet will be brittle and will break into small pieces. Try to recover as much as possible with 1mL pipette.

If the pellet breaks apart too much, add 1.5mL fresh 70% EtOH to the 50mL Faclon and spin for 5min at 4000g.

Remove 1mL and transfer the remaining volume and DNA pellet to same 2mL eppendorf tube.

components.data: Spin in table top centrifuge for 5 mins at 13000g
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Spin in table top centrifuge for 5 mins at 13000g

components.data: Remove supernatant with pipette and wash with 1.5mL fresh 70% Ethanol, invert several times to dislodge pellet
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove supernatant with pipette and wash with 1.5mL fresh 70% Ethanol, invert several times to dislodge pellet

components.data: Spin in table top centrifuge for 5 mins at 13000g. Repeat wash steps (21-24).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Spin in table top centrifuge for 5 mins at 13000g. Repeat wash steps (21-24).

components.data: Pour off ethanol and remove remaining ethanol with pipette. Spin down briefly and remove any remaining ethanol with pipette.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pour off ethanol and remove remaining ethanol with pipette. Spin down briefly and remove any remaining ethanol with pipette.
Air-dry pellet for 2-3 mins

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 24 of High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio, Nanopore MinION

source_data.annotation: Hi Megan, what do you mean by 2-2 minutes? The timer says 7 minutes, did you mean 2-7 minutes?
source_data.thread_text: Hi Megan, what do you mean by 2-2 minutes? The timer says 7 minutes, did you mean 2-7 minutes?
source_data.body: Hi Megan, what do you mean by 2-2 minutes? The timer says 7 minutes, did you mean 2-7 minutes?

comments.name: Megan McDonald
comments.comment_text:
Hi Jet,

 

Looks like a small typo there, sorry.

 

Should be 2-3 min. I don't like to dry my pellet too long becasue that can make it much more difficult to dissolve.

 

Made changes in the protocol. 

 

Best,

Megan
comments.body:
Hi Jet,

 

Looks like a small typo there, sorry.

 

Should be 2-3 min. I don't like to dry my pellet too long becasue that can make it much more difficult to dissolve.

 

Made changes in the protocol. 

 

Best,

Megan

components.data: Add 200uL (or desired final volume) of 10mM Tris pH8.5 leave at RT until dissolved
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 200uL (or desired final volume) of 10mM Tris pH8.5 leave at RT until dissolved

components.data: Flick tube slightly for mixing. DO NOT! vortex as it shears DNA.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Flick tube slightly for mixing. DO NOT! vortex as it shears DNA.

components.data:
Measure dsDNA concentration using BR Qubit and measure absorbance with Nanodrop.
This might be also a good step to assess DNA quality by runing a 0.8% TBE agarose gel with 500ng dsDNA and a lamda-Hind-III ladder as control.

If you have a Pulse Field Gel Electrophoresis around even better.

 

 

Qubit to Nanodrop ratio varies widely from fungal species to fungal species.

See next step below for comparisons before/after clean up with a silica column
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Measure dsDNA concentration using BR Qubit and measure absorbance with Nanodrop.
This might be also a good step to assess DNA quality by runing a 0.8% TBE agarose gel with 500ng dsDNA and a lamda-Hind-III ladder as control.

If you have a Pulse Field Gel Electrophoresis around even better.

 

 

Qubit to Nanodrop ratio varies widely from fungal species to fungal species.

See next step below for comparisons before/after clean up with a silica column

components.data:
Measure DNA concentration with the Qubit and Nanodrop.

 

The closer your nanodrop measurement is to your Qubit the better.

Typical values after my DNA extractions are:

 

B. sorokiniana CS27

Sample Volume Qubit ng/uL Nano ng/uL 260/230 260/280
CS27  200 uL 65  1389  1.94 1.92
CS27-2 200uL 84 1800 1.92. 1.93
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Measure DNA concentration with the Qubit and Nanodrop.

 

The closer your nanodrop measurement is to your Qubit the better.

Typical values after my DNA extractions are:

 

B. sorokiniana CS27

Sample Volume Qubit ng/uL Nano ng/uL 260/230 260/280
CS27  200 uL 65  1389  1.94 1.92
CS27-2 200uL 84 1800 1.92. 1.93

components.data:
Use AMPure beads (or cheaper versions) for secondary clean up at beads 0.45 (Vol/Vol) following the PacBio protocol.

Repeat AMPure bead clean-up at LEAST TWICE before starting MinIon Library Prep.

 

Run agarose gel to check for remaining RNA, small fragmets or smears. You want your sample to look like Lane 4 (Ampure) where there is NO visible smear on the lower parts of the gel.

 

 

I you have low amounts of DNA you should add a higher volume of beads to your sample to retain more DNA. NOTE: Adding higher volume will keep a lot more of the smaller fragments.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Use AMPure beads (or cheaper versions) for secondary clean up at beads 0.45 (Vol/Vol) following the PacBio protocol.

Repeat AMPure bead clean-up at LEAST TWICE before starting MinIon Library Prep.

 

Run agarose gel to check for remaining RNA, small fragmets or smears. You want your sample to look like Lane 4 (Ampure) where there is NO visible smear on the lower parts of the gel.

 

 

I you have low amounts of DNA you should add a higher volume of beads to your sample to retain more DNA. NOTE: Adding higher volume will keep a lot more of the smaller fragments.

components.data: Elute in 50 uL 10mM Tris pH8, and measure dsDNA concentration using BR Qubit and measure absorbance with Nanodrop
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Elute in 50 uL 10mM Tris pH8, and measure dsDNA concentration using BR Qubit and measure absorbance with Nanodrop

components.data:
Stats shown below are for sample CS27-amp2

Used 5 ug of starting DNA for 1D Nanopore MinION Library prep. 

Remaining DNA after FFPE repair: ~3.75 ug

Remaining DNA after daTailing ~2.7 ug

Remaining DNA after Adapter Lig ~1 ug

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 34 of High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio, Nanopore MinION
source_data.protocol_name: High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio, Nanopore MinION
source_data.protocol_name_html: High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio, Nanopore MinION
source_data.annotation:
Hi Megan,

 

I'm surprised by your recovery rate (1.8 ug final library from 4 ug input DNA). Are you following the 1D protocol with all bead cleanups?

- 0.4X beads: initial DNA cleanup / removing short fragments.

- 1X beads: after nick repair

- 1X beads: after end repair

- 0.4X beads: after adapter ligation

 

Typically we recover 90% of DNA from 1X bead cleanups, but the 0.4X bead cleanups only recover about 50% of the DNA. Following the 1D protocol with bead cleanups as described above, with 4.0 ug input DNA we would probably have only about 800 ng in the adapted library.

 

Thanks!

Matt
source_data.thread_text:
Hi Megan,

 

I'm surprised by your recovery rate (1.8 ug final library from 4 ug input DNA). Are you following the 1D protocol with all bead cleanups?

- 0.4X beads: initial DNA cleanup / removing short fragments.

- 1X beads: after nick repair

- 1X beads: after end repair

- 0.4X beads: after adapter ligation

 

Typically we recover 90% of DNA from 1X bead cleanups, but the 0.4X bead cleanups only recover about 50% of the DNA. Following the 1D protocol with bead cleanups as described above, with 4.0 ug input DNA we would probably have only about 800 ng in the adapted library.

 

Thanks!

Matt
source_data.body:
Hi Megan,

 

I'm surprised by your recovery rate (1.8 ug final library from 4 ug input DNA). Are you following the 1D protocol with all bead cleanups?

- 0.4X beads: initial DNA cleanup / removing short fragments.

- 1X beads: after nick repair

- 1X beads: after end repair

- 0.4X beads: after adapter ligation

 

Typically we recover 90% of DNA from 1X bead cleanups, but the 0.4X bead cleanups only recover about 50% of the DNA. Following the 1D protocol with bead cleanups as described above, with 4.0 ug input DNA we would probably have only about 800 ng in the adapted library.

 

Thanks!

Matt

comments.name: Megan McDonald
comments.comment_text:
Hi Matt,

 

Those recovery's sound about right to me. 

 

My 4 ug is what goes into the nick repair step, so that would eliminate the first 0.4 clean-up you mention above. Getting much closer to the 1.8 I loaded, assuming 90, 90, 50% recovery in the next 3 steps.

 

Last run I did I started with 10ug:

- 1X beads: after nick repair 9.1 ug

- 1X beads: after end repair 8.3 ug

- 0.4X beads: after adapter ligation 3.2 

So that 's a bit lower than 50% recovery on the last step.

 

Every DNA sample is different though, for the DNA extraction itself I get a wide range of output DNA anywhere between 30-10 ug depending on how much mycelia/spores I start with.

 

Does this help?

 

Megan
comments.body:
Hi Matt,

 

Those recovery's sound about right to me. 

 

My 4 ug is what goes into the nick repair step, so that would eliminate the first 0.4 clean-up you mention above. Getting much closer to the 1.8 I loaded, assuming 90, 90, 50% recovery in the next 3 steps.

 

Last run I did I started with 10ug:

- 1X beads: after nick repair 9.1 ug

- 1X beads: after end repair 8.3 ug

- 0.4X beads: after adapter ligation 3.2 

So that 's a bit lower than 50% recovery on the last step.

 

Every DNA sample is different though, for the DNA extraction itself I get a wide range of output DNA anywhere between 30-10 ug depending on how much mycelia/spores I start with.

 

Does this help?

 

Megan

components.data:
Transfer supernatant to fresh 50 mL Falcon tube.  If solution remains milky, repeat P/C/I wash. If solution is clear proceed to DNA precipitation.

 

Usually I am able to transfer ~15 mL of the supernatant.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Transfer supernatant to fresh 50 mL Falcon tube.  If solution remains milky, repeat P/C/I wash. If solution is clear proceed to DNA precipitation.

 

Usually I am able to transfer ~15 mL of the supernatant.

components.data:
Wash pellet in 5mL of fresh 70% EtOH. Gently tap tube to dislodge the pellet from the side to get a thorough wash.

 

Spin 3000-5000g for 3-5 min to stick pellet back to the side of the falcon tube.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Wash pellet in 5mL of fresh 70% EtOH. Gently tap tube to dislodge the pellet from the side to get a thorough wash.

 

Spin 3000-5000g for 3-5 min to stick pellet back to the side of the falcon tube.

components.data:
For most fungal species I've worked with there is a contaminant that co-purifies with the AMPure beads and absorbs at 230 on the Nanodrop.

This means that my 260/230 ratios for the Nanodrop are always low (1.0-1.7). The more purification you do with AMPure the worse this ratio gets...haven't found a solution yet. MinIion or PacBio sequencing with a low 260/230 ratio still works well (you get long reads), though your total output data may be less than a sample with a better ratio.

Example of Nanodrop values decreasing with every AMPure clean up:

 

Sample Volume Qubit ng/uL Nano ng/uL 260/230 260/280
CS27  200 uL 65  1389  1.94 1.92
CS27-amp1 100 uL 114 291 1.74 1.09
CS27-amp2 50 uL 102 305 1.68 0.92

 

 

 

NOTE^3:Ampure beads sometimes don't always collect nicely on the side of the tube. If this happens I remove the supernatant as best I can (SAVE IT!). Then BREIFLY spin the tube to help the beads pellet. (The more you spin the more you will shear your DNA). Remove as much as the supernatant as you can. Then proceed to next step. During 70% EtOH wash with beads, gently rotate the 1.5mL tube 360º on the magnet. The beads will slowly follow as you rotate. This helps get a better wash.

 

If your final ellution doesn't contain DNA, you can recover it from the SAVED supernate from the very first step. To recover add equal volume of beads to this saved supernatant and proceed with normal protocol.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
For most fungal species I've worked with there is a contaminant that co-purifies with the AMPure beads and absorbs at 230 on the Nanodrop.

This means that my 260/230 ratios for the Nanodrop are always low (1.0-1.7). The more purification you do with AMPure the worse this ratio gets...haven't found a solution yet. MinIion or PacBio sequencing with a low 260/230 ratio still works well (you get long reads), though your total output data may be less than a sample with a better ratio.

Example of Nanodrop values decreasing with every AMPure clean up:

 

Sample Volume Qubit ng/uL Nano ng/uL 260/230 260/280
CS27  200 uL 65  1389  1.94 1.92
CS27-amp1 100 uL 114 291 1.74 1.09
CS27-amp2 50 uL 102 305 1.68 0.92

 

 

 

NOTE^3:Ampure beads sometimes don't always collect nicely on the side of the tube. If this happens I remove the supernatant as best I can (SAVE IT!). Then BREIFLY spin the tube to help the beads pellet. (The more you spin the more you will shear your DNA). Remove as much as the supernatant as you can. Then proceed to next step. During 70% EtOH wash with beads, gently rotate the 1.5mL tube 360º on the magnet. The beads will slowly follow as you rotate. This helps get a better wash.

 

If your final ellution doesn't contain DNA, you can recover it from the SAVED supernate from the very first step. To recover add equal volume of beads to this saved supernatant and proceed with normal protocol.

source_data.thread_title: Comment on step 32 of High quality DNA from Fungi for long read sequencing e.g. PacBio, Nanopore MinION

source_data.annotation:
Hi Megan,

 

Do you have any update in this 230nm contamination issue?

 

Thanks,

Caio
source_data.thread_text:
Hi Megan,

 

Do you have any update in this 230nm contamination issue?

 

Thanks,

Caio
source_data.body:
Hi Megan,

 

Do you have any update in this 230nm contamination issue?

 

Thanks,

Caio

comments.name: Megan McDonald
comments.comment_text:
Hi Caio,

 

Thanks for your interest. Unfortunately no I haven't really improved upon this issue. 

 

@Benjaminschwessinger and his PhD student Ram have made some improvements I think but I haven't tried out that protocol yet. I just spoke with Ram and he said he needs to update the protocol again, I think it's this one (dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.n5ydg7w). He said he gets really good 230 ratios but the sequencing data wasn't good from this protocol. He has made some improvements though and will update the site soon. (Probably faster if you ask him a question :))

 

I can say from my part I'm sequencing with bad 230 ratios and I get on average 3-4Gb of basecalled data that's usable.

 

Cheers,

Megan
comments.body:
Hi Caio,

 

Thanks for your interest. Unfortunately no I haven't really improved upon this issue. 

 

@Benjaminschwessinger and his PhD student Ram have made some improvements I think but I haven't tried out that protocol yet. I just spoke with Ram and he said he needs to update the protocol again, I think it's this one (dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.n5ydg7w). He said he gets really good 230 ratios but the sequencing data wasn't good from this protocol. He has made some improvements though and will update the site soon. (Probably faster if you ask him a question :))

 

I can say from my part I'm sequencing with bad 230 ratios and I get on average 3-4Gb of basecalled data that's usable.

 

Cheers,

Megan

comments.name: Caio Leal-Dutra
comments.comment_text:
Hi Megan,

Thank you very much for your reply. 

 

I was having this problem with the ampure beads making the 230 ratios worse. But using the homemade ampure. In my cas,e I removed the EDTA from the beads buffer and it worked.

 

But I am still having some problems with the extraction. I will refer to Benjamin's protocol and see if it improves my DNA quality.

 

Kind regards,

Caio
comments.body:
Hi Megan,

Thank you very much for your reply. 

 

I was having this problem with the ampure beads making the 230 ratios worse. But using the homemade ampure. In my cas,e I removed the EDTA from the beads buffer and it worked.

 

But I am still having some problems with the extraction. I will refer to Benjamin's protocol and see if it improves my DNA quality.

 

Kind regards,

Caio
